header.title: STEPMod Configuration Management User Guide - Working with a module

section.title: Overview
section.p: This section of the user guide aims to illustrate the possible actions that can be taken on a part using the STEPMod CM tool. The nutty_bolts resource document will be used in this illustration. Where appropriate links are given to the relevant "How to" sections on the index page.

section.title: Nutty Bolts Examples
section.p: The following how to sections are designed to show what can be done to a module.
Start by loading a repository index. see the how to load a repository index section

section.title: Before working with a part
section.p: Once a repository _index has been loaded it is important to ensure that the correct releases of the 'Common Files' and the 'STEPMod Framework' are checked out.
To do this, expand the Common Files icon.
Right click on the AP239_20050817 and select Checkout specified release. A dialog box like the following will appear.
Do the same for the STEPMod Framework.
The application GUI should now look like this:
section.note: The yellow highlight indicates which version is currently checked out.
section.p: Then run a CVS update on all CM records

img.alt: A CVS Update on all CM records

section.p: Once a repository index has been loaded and the CVS update has completed; navigate to the part you wish to work with. In this case the part is the resource document nutty_bolts.

section.title: Create a CM Record

img.alt: nutty bolts in the repository index

section.p: The above image clearly shows the nutty_bolts resource document highlighted. The panel on the right hand side shows the information relating to the part; including the fact that the CM_record does not yet exist. The icon next to the CVS part also reflects this.
It is also possible to confirm this by navigating to the configuration_management directory that resides under the STEPMod root directory.
The above image clearly shows that there is no resource_docs directory and therefore no CM_record.
To create a CM record, select the part. Then right click and select CM record -> Create and save CM Record.
The following dialog box will appear.
Select yes. The dialog box will then disappear. A CM record will be created in the configuration_management directory.
section.note: At this point the CM record has been created but only contains comments about what should appear in the file. The record contains no release information as no releases have been made yet. The picture below shows the generated content.

section.title: Commit a CM record
section.p: Upon creating the CM record the icon in the STEPMod CM tool changes to red. The comment in the right hand pane of the tool changes to read: "The CM record file, cm_record.xml, has been committed to CVS but the local file has changed". This means that the file has changed (in this instance it has been created) and needs to be committed to CVS.
In order to commit the CM Record right click on the part and select CM record -> Commit CM record.
A dialog box will appear asking you to confirm the commit. Select yes.
Once the CM record has been committed to CVS the icon will change again.
At this point the new CM record has been created and committed. However it still does not contain any release information, as no releases have been made.

section.title: Create a new release
section.p: To create a new release right click on the part and select Release -> Create new release.
In this instance the application returns a warning message.
In order to checkout the dependent parts as releases click OK then navigate to view the dependencies.

The image above shows that the nutty_bolts resource document is dependent upon three resource schemas. The released versions of these schemas need to be checked out in order to create a release of the nutty_bolts part. However when right clicking and selecting the checkout latest release option it becomes apparent that there are no releases available.
In order to rectify this navigate to the resource schemas.
And select the three resource schemas in question.
Then go to the Selected file menu and select the Create and commit CM records for selected parts. Click OK on the dialog boxes that appear.

The icons will change to reflect the fact that the parts now have CM records and that they are committed to CVS. In order to create multiple releases go back to the Selected menu and choose the Release selected parts option from the release sub menu.
This will bring up the following dialog box
For this example the resource document and schemas will be released for Team review. Click OK once you have added a description.
The parts will then be tagged as a release.
Once the dependent parts have been released or the latest releases of the dependent parts have been checked out you can then release the nutty_bolts CM record.
Navigate back to the resource document nutty_bolts. Go to the Selected menu and click Release -> Release selected parts.
As before the release dialog box will appear.
Click Ok. The application will tag the part as a release.
The image shows that a new release has been created under releases. It also shows that the cm_record.xml file has changed locally and that it needs to be committed to SourceForge. see here
Once the part has been released the CM record will hold the release information. This can be verified by navigating to the configuration_management directory and viewing the contents of the xml file.
The above image clearly shows the release information specified when releasing the resource document nutty_bolts.

section.title: Convert tagged revisions of selected parts to a Release
section.p: When a part has been published it is tagged.
It is possible to use the STEPMod CM tool to convert these tagged revisions into a release by taking the following actions.
Select the part in question
Got to the Selected menu and select Releases -> Convert tagged revisions of selected parts to a release.
A box like the following should appear and you should be able to create a release
Once a release has been made the CM_record will have to be committed.
If the selected part has not been tagged then you will not be able to create convert the tagged revision to a release.
A dialog like the following will appear.
Once the tagged revision has been converted into a release it will be visible as a release in the tool.
